title: 105_hr4093
content: The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It establishes a standard relating to hospital lengths of stay for group health plans under the Public Health Service Act. The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" requires group health plans to provide inpatient coverage for a medically appropriate period determined by a physician. It prohibits denying eligibility based on coverage requirements and penalizing providers for following the act. The "Hospital Stay Protection Act" mandates group health plans to cover inpatient stays as determined by a physician, prohibits denial of eligibility based on coverage requirements, and penalizes plans for violations. An appeals process and penalty system will be established by the Secretary in consultation with the Secretary of Labor. Compliance with notice requirements under ERISA is also required. The text chunk provides amendments to the "Hospital Stay Protection Act" regarding the required summary description and clerical changes to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. Amendments are made to the Hospital Stay Protection Act, including a new section on standards for hospital lengths of stay under individual health insurance. The provisions of section 2706 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market, with a notice requirement for health insurance issuers. A conforming amendment is made to include section 2752. Effective dates for group market reforms are specified. Effective Dates: The amendments for group market reforms apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1999. Special rules apply to group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before that date. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market starting on January 1, 1999. Any plan amendment made to conform to new requirements shall not be considered a termination of a collective bargaining agreement. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended to coordinate regulations with the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, the Public Health Service Act, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
